question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which organization was Alan Wilson a member of in 2045?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Pursuit of Excellence: Unveiling the Distinguished Career of Alan Wilson"

In the realm of biomechanics, few names resonate as profoundly as Alan Wilson, a British scientist whose groundbreaking contributions have left an indelible mark on the field. As we delve into the remarkable journey of this esteemed researcher, a singular honor stands out among his numerous accolades: his membership in the prestigious Royal Society, England's oldest and most revered learned society for science. Founded in 1660, the Royal Society has been the bastion of scientific excellence, counting among its fellows some of the most brilliant minds in history, including Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, and Stephen Hawking. To be elected a Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) is to join an elite group of individuals who have made significant contributions to their respective fields, pushing the boundaries of human knowledge and understanding. Alan Wilson's path to this distinction began with his early fascination with the intricacies of human movement and the biomechanical principles that govern it. His undergraduate studies in physiology at the University of Leeds laid the foundation for a career that would take him to the forefront of biomechanical research. Wilson's doctoral work at the University of London focused on the mechanics of human locomotion, setting the stage for a lifelong pursuit of understanding the complex interactions between the human body and its environment. As Wilson's reputation grew, so did his influence. He became a leading authority on the biomechanics of sports injuries, publishing seminal papers on the causes and prevention of injuries in athletes. His work with the British Olympic Association and the International Olympic Committee further solidified his position as a global expert in the field. In 2004, the Royal Society recognized Wilson's outstanding contributions to biomechanics by electing him a Fellow. This honor, reserved for those who have demonstrated exceptional scientific merit, marked a pinnacle in Wilson's career. The Society's citation praised his "pioneering work on the biomechanics of human movement, particularly in the context of sports injuries and rehabilitation." Wilson's membership in the Royal Society is a testament to his dedication to advancing the field of biomechanics. His election to the Society's ranks is a reflection of the esteem in which he is held by his peers, who recognize the significance of his research and its far-reaching implications for human health and performance. Through his work, Alan Wilson has not only expanded our understanding of the human body but has also inspired a new generation of researchers to pursue careers in biomechanics.
content.source_2: In the year 2026, the world was on the cusp of a revolution in biomechanics. Alan Wilson, a brilliant British scientist, had just been recruited by AFRISTAT, an international institution dedicated to collecting and analyzing statistics in Sub-Saharan Africa. As a member of the esteemed organization, Alan was tasked with applying his expertise in biomechanics to improve the lives of millions of people across the continent. February 2026 marked the beginning of Alan's journey with AFRISTAT. He arrived at the institution's headquarters in Dakar, Senegal, filled with excitement and a sense of purpose. Over the next few months, he immersed himself in the organization's work, studying the complex relationships between statistics, economics, and human development. As the years went by, Alan's contributions to AFRISTAT grew exponentially. He developed innovative solutions to improve healthcare outcomes, enhance agricultural productivity, and promote sustainable urban planning. His work took him to remote villages in Mali, bustling cities in Nigeria, and everything in between. Wherever he went, Alan's passion for biomechanics and his commitment to the people of Sub-Saharan Africa earned him the respect and admiration of his colleagues and the communities he served. The 2030s were a transformative period for AFRISTAT, and Alan was at the forefront of the change. He played a key role in the development of cutting-edge technologies, such as advanced prosthetics and wearable devices, which improved the lives of countless individuals across the continent. His work also helped to inform policy decisions, shaping the course of economic development and social progress in Sub-Saharan Africa. As the years turned into decades, Alan's reputation as a leading expert in biomechanics and statistics continued to grow. He became a sought-after speaker at international conferences, sharing his insights and expertise with audiences around the world. Despite his many accomplishments, however, Alan remained humble and dedicated to his work, always seeking new ways to make a positive impact on the world. November 2040 marked the end of Alan's remarkable 14-year tenure with AFRISTAT. As he looked back on his time with the organization, he felt a deep sense of pride and fulfillment. He had made a difference, and he knew that his work would continue to inspire and empower future generations. As Alan Wilson departed AFRISTAT, he left behind a legacy that would endure for years to come.
